p:
Let
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$h(x,y)$$\end{document}
h ( x , y )
be a function representing intensity of human activities at coordinates
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$(x,y)$$\end{document}
( x , y )
. Without loss of generality, we can assume that the function
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$h(x,y)$$\end{document}
h ( x , y )
satisfies
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\int_{S} {h(x,y)\,dxdy} = 1$$\end{document}
∫ S
h ( x , y )
d x d y
= 1
, the total intensity over the study area is scaled to one. In the source-mediated-dispersal model, the source function is proportional to the human-activity intensity, i.e.,
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\varphi (x,y) = |S| \cdot h(x,y)$$\end{document}
φ ( x , y ) = | S | · h ( x , y )
, and the destination function
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\psi (x,y)$$\end{document}
ψ ( x , y )
is uniformly equal to
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 {|S|}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {|S|}}$$\end{document}
1
/
| S |
. On the contrary, the source function of the destination-mediated-dispersal model is uniform and the destination function is
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\psi (x,y) = h(x,y)$$\end{document}
ψ ( x , y ) = h ( x , y )
. The full model is a combination of the source- and destination-mediated-dispersal models in which both source and destination functions vary with area. In this study, we assume that a single factor determines both the source and destination functions, i.e.,
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\varphi (x,y) = \left| S \right| \cdot h(x,y)$$\end{document}
φ
( x , y )
=
S
· h
( x , y )
and
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\psi (x,y) = h(x,y)$$\end{document}
ψ ( x , y ) = h ( x , y )
(Table 2).
